Name: n-Heptacosane
Description: Heptacosane is a straight-chain alkane with 27 carbon atoms. It has a role as a volatile oil component and a plant metabolite.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) US Dept Agric; US Dept Agric, Agric Res Service. 1992-2016. Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases. Heptacosane. Available from, as of Jan 18, 2017: https://phytochem.nal.usda.gov/phytochem/search

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Butts DP et al; Comparative Biochem Physiol B 99: 87-91 (1991). Available from, as of Jan 18, 2017: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0305049191900123 (2) Tartivita K, Jackson LL; Lipids 5: 35-37 (1970). Available from, as of Jan 18, 2017: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF02531091 (3) Shibue K et al; Anal Sciences 20: 1729-31 (2004). Available from, as of Jan 18, 2017: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15636525
animal_concentrations.Value: Heptacosane was found in several species of wasps, including Dolichovespula maculata and Vespula maculifrons; it was the major hydrocarbon at 14% in Vespula squamosa(1). The compound was found in the cuticular surface lipids of the cockroaches Leucophaea maderae and Blatta orientalis(2). Heptacosane was found in several species of fireflies including Lucidota atra, Photuris lucicrescens and Photuris cinctipennis(3).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Al-Hassan JM et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 66: 646-52 (2001)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Catfish (Arius bilineatus) collected from seven locations in the Arabian Gulf had concentrations of C27 alkanes ranging from not detected to 2.9 ng/g wet weight(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Hori et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 83: 455-61 (2009)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Heptacosane concentrations were 7.7-429 ng/g dry weight in sediments samples collected from 14 sites from the Shinano River in Niigata, Japan from November 2005 to April 2006(1).
